docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. M. Jodi Rell proposed a health care plan yesterday that she said would give thousands of state residents without insurance access to lower-cost medical care. Under the plan, any state resident who has been uninsured for more than six months would be able to join the program and pay a premium of about $250 a month, with co-payments of $10 to $15 for prescription drugs. Mrs. Rell said several insurers had indicated interest in participating. The state would not contribute any money to the program, Mrs. Rell said, but would market and advertise it. She said insurers might be willing to accept lower premiums in exchange for access to new customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Depriving children of adequate health care while giving the rich tax benefits that were intended for average Americans is flat-out wrong, and Congress must move quickly to prevent that.

docs.lead_paragraph: S.E.C. CHANGES OPTIONS RULE -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reversed a decision it had made just months earlier, adopting instead a rule that will allow many companies to report significantly lower total compensation for top executives. [Page A1.] MORSE CODE'S FADING SIGNAL -- Some Morse Code buffs, shaken by news that the government will no longer require Morse Code proficiency as a condition for an amateur radio license, fear that their exclusive club has been opened to the masses -- and that the very survival of Morse Code may be in question. Nancy Kott, editor of World Radio magazine, calls the move ''part of the dumbing-down of America.'' [C1.] MCCLATCHY SELLS NEWSPAPER -- The McClatchy Company, the newspaper publisher, said that it was selling The Star Tribune of Minneapolis to a private equity firm, Avista Capital Partners, for $530 million, citing the lagging performance of the paper and the tax advantages from the sale. [C1.] AN UNDERDOG RAMPS UP -- Willis Group Holdings has become the fastest-growing corporate insurance broker, and speculation persists that it wants to buy Marsh & McLennan Companies, the longtime industry leader. [C1.] ELUSIVE GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS -- Some entrepreneurs complain that federal contracts set aside for small businesses often go to big companies, and that rules intended to give them recourse in such cases are cumbersome and rarely enforced. [C1.] BRAIN POWER FOR SALE -- Brain health programs are springing up across the country, aimed at baby boomers anxious about entering their golden years and at their parents, who are trying to stave off memory loss. [A1.] GAZPROM WANTS ITS PRICE -- Gazprom, the Russian energy monopoly, threatened to halt natural gas supplies to Belarus if that country did not agree to a large price increase by the first of the year. The strong Russian position suggests that Moscow is becoming aggressive in energy pricing even with countries that have been close allies. [A5.] SOME DRUG PLANS FOUND REMISS -- Some prescription drug plans did not inform Medicare beneficiaries of impending changes in their costs and benefits, as they were required to do, Bush administration officials and Congressional aides said. [A18.] PRIVATE EQUITY IN ASIA -- After the extraordinary growth in private equity deals in the United States and Europe, Asia may be emerging as the next frontier. [C3.] DEAL FOR GAS FIELDS -- The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, the oil and natural gas producer, sold gas fields in Louisiana to Exco Resources for $1.6 billion to help cut debt, the companies said. [C3.] REFCO EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY -- Refco Inc., the onetime futures and commodities broker, said that it had emerged from bankruptcy protection, a move that will allow the company to wind up its businesses. [C3.] ADVICE FROM TOYOTA -- The new chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, Alan R. Mulally, met last week in Tokyo with the chairman of Toyota Motor Company, Fujio Cho, to discuss the development of environmentally friendly technology, like hybrid electric and hydrogen fuel systems, as well as ways Toyota could help Ford improve its manufacturing efficiency. [C1.] PAY CUT FOR TYSON EXECUTIVES -- Tyson Foods has cut the pay of its chairman, John Tyson, and chief executive, Richard L. Bond, by withholding bonuses after the company suffered its first yearly loss since 1994. [C5.] SHARES SPRING BACK -- Wall Street rebounded in light trading as lower oil prices encouraged investors to add to their portfolios in the final days of the year. [C8.] ONLINE ENERGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT -- In a series of articles, a team of Times reporters has described how the world is, and is not, moving toward a more secure and less environmentally damaging relationship with energy. Several writers will respond to questions and comments on Thursday. The series is at nytimes.com/business. THE YEAR IN PICTURES -- Whether it was the deteriorating situation in Iraq, or shifting political winds in Washington, 2006 was a year of big changes. An interactive feature spotlighting the year in photographs is at nytimes.com/multimedia. WILLING TO BE LUCKY -- The Museum of the City of New York has served up a copious slice of New York's cultural life in the mid-20th century in ''Willing to Be Lucky: Ambitious New Yorkers in the Pages of Look Magazine.'' A slide show is at nytimes.com/multimedia. RECLAIMING THE REVOLUTION -- New Jersey takes a big step toward gaining wider recognition of the region's role in the Revolutionary War. You can see the article and slide show at nytimes.com/nyregion.

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, the health-insurance giant, said Tuesday that it has received a formal order of investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission related to stock-options backdating. The order was issued Dec. 19, after regulators first notified the company in April of an informal inquiry. UnitedHealth said in its filing that it is cooperating with the investigation. In October, the company fired its longtime chief executive, Dr. William W. McGuire, as well as its general counsel and a raft of other top executives in connection with the timing of options doled out to employees.
